awd_titl_txt: Synthesis and Spectroscopy of Complex Halide and Chalcogenide Nanocrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
Semiconductor nanostructures are critical components of many energy and information technologies, and they will be central to numerous future technologies including advanced forms of communications and data processing. This research is generating new forms of matter on nanometer length scales made from semiconductors with complex and unexplored compositions. This project is enabling capabilities that will allow researchers to synthesize these new classes of semiconductors, and it is advancing the fundamental understanding of such materials through combined materials development and physical characterization studies, thereby expanding the frontiers of nanoscience. In addition to yielding new scientific knowledge and new forms of matter, this project is also providing technical training for participating undergraduate and graduate students to prepare them for future careers in science, engineering, education, and related fields. The impact of this project is broadened by integrating research and education at early-career levels through engagement of undergraduates, incorporation of research concepts into undergraduate curricula, collaboration with faculty from undergraduate institutions (and hosting such faculty and their undergraduate students), and mature community outreach activities.

Technical Abstract: 
This project is targeting discovery and development of new complex semiconductor nanostructures, development of new synthetic methodologies, and use of spectroscopic, analytical, and computational tools to elucidate key structure/function relationships in these complex materials, with the overarching goal of accelerating technological innovations involving these materials. The project focuses specifically on colloidal ternary, quaternary, and doped haloperovskite-type semiconductor nanocrystals, including mixed-metal elpasolites, and colloidal ternary, alloyed, and doped chalcopyrite-type nanocrystals, including CuInS2. These materials offer timely new opportunities to access unprecedented physical properties with technological value. This project is also advancing the chemistries and physical understanding of lead- and cadmium-free semiconductor nanocrystals that may ultimately replace well-known systems based on these ions as workhorses in future technologies. Overall, this project is yielding new materials, new fundamental knowledge, advanced training for participants, and ultimately new materials platforms for future energy conversion, information processing, sensing, and other optoelectronic technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Washington Department of Chemistry

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

This project investigated the synthesis and spectroscopic properties of colloidal inorganic nanocrystals with complex and often highly challenging compositions. This project developed innovative synthetic methods for preparation of novel metal-chalcogenide and metal-halide nanocrystals with undoped, doped, and alloy compositions, using chemistry to tune their physical properties such as photoluminescence or magnetism and to develop a fundamental understanding of electronic structure features relevant to future photonics, spin-photonics, quantum, and solar energy technologies. The project explored the fundamental science of dopants and defects in such inorganic nanostructures, pioneering their use to control physical functionalities of potential technological interest, leading to discoveries of new semiconductor, magnetic, and insulator materials never previously isolated or studied.

 

Intellectual merit. This project developed and applied a combination of synthesis, spectroscopic measurements, and other analytical and theoretical methods to elucidate fundamental structure/function relationships in luminescent colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals relevant to spin-photonics, energy conversion, quantum information, and heterogeneous catalysis. This project pioneered the development and spectroscopy of unique photon-multiplying doped metal-halide perovskite nanocrystals (and corresponding bulk materials), showing that they have the potential to vastly improve the efficiency of conventional silicon solar cells. This project also pioneered the development of luminescent magnetic nanocrystals and related nanostructures, particularly focusing on the roles of dopants and defects to manipulate or shape the magnetic or photophysical properties of these nanostructures. Detailed investigations into electronic structure led to fundamentally new insights into how the geometric and electronic structures in these materials generate the observed physical properties. This project generated a portfolio of new materials with attractive photophysical, photomagnetic, or magneto-optical properties, and it led to advances in methodologies and in fundamental knowledge. The new materials, methodologies, and basic knowledge, generated from this project may ultimately accelerate the development of advanced future technologies involving functional inorganic materials.

 

Broader impact. This project has yielded new functional inorganic materials and new fundamental knowledge relevant to a wide variety of energy conversion, storage, and efficiency technologies, as well as to various sensing, catalysis, and information technologies. This project's integration of synthesis with spectroscopy and electronic-structure studies has helped bridge the fields of nanocrystal chemistry, physics, analytical chemistry, and technology and has provided advanced interdisciplinary education and training opportunities for participating students and postdoctoral researchers. Participants collaborated with researchers on and off campus, and engaged in mature education, outreach, and professional-development programs at UW, preparing them for fruitful careers in science, engineering, and education. This project engaged several undergraduates, providing them early career research opportunities and facilitating their progress toward STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) higher education and professional employment. This project supported the PI's activities in launching and organizing a biennial regional conference for Pacific Northwest students and researchers involved in nanoscience, emphasizing integration across the nanoscience education ecosystem from primarily undergraduate institutions to regional national laboratories and industry.


Last Modified: 01/31/2025
Modified by: Daniel R Gamelin
